I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Strategy 2020 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) recognizes the need for Asia and 
the Pacific to pursue “open regionalism,” keeping trade and investment links open with the rest 
of the world.1 ADB’s Strategy 2020 also aims to increase regional cooperation and integration 
(RCI) in all operational areas, and increase assistance for RCI to at least 30% of total activities 
by 2020. In view of the developments in the regional economic landscape,2 the ADB Midterm 
Review of Strategy 2020 highlighted the need for a "second generation RCI" agenda and 
reiterated the 30% target.3  In order to translate the midterm review agenda for RCI into future 
RCI operations, ADB decided to develop an RCI Operational Plan.4  
 
2.  This technical assistance (TA) will support the implementation of the midterm review’s 
recommendations under a proposed RCI Operational Plan by producing operationally-relevant 
knowledge work to guide ADB’s future operations in RCI. The TA will build on the success of 
past ADB flagship publications on RCI and various subregional ADB programs.5 The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Regionalism in Asia and the Pacific is market-driven, dynamic, open, multitrack, and 
multispeed, owing to different development patterns, economic circumstances, and geopolitical 
realities across the region. This model of regionalism has served the region well, with RCI 
playing an increasingly important role in the region’s economic development. 
 
4.  ADB  has  sought  to  take  the  process  of  regionalism  forward  through  a  bottom-up 
approach built on support to subregional cooperation efforts (e.g., the Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations [ASEAN], ASEAN+37; the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation; the 
Greater Mekong Subregion; and the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation), with a 
focus on cross-border infrastructure and related software (Pillar 1), trade and investment (Pillar 
2), monetary and financial cooperation (Pillar 3), and regional public goods (Pillar 4). These 
subregional cooperation efforts have progressed at different speeds and serve as building 
blocks for an eventual broader and more unified regional architecture. 
 
5.   Recent analyses by ADB have revealed that significant progress has been made in 
harnessing RCI for development.8 Stronger intra-regional linkages in trade, investment, financial 
assets, and labor flows have helped Asia and the Pacific weather heightened volatility and 
weaker global demand in the wake of the 2008/2009 global financial crisis. In particular, intra-
regional trade remained robust at 55% of total trade in 2014, while intra-regional foreign direct 
investment (FDI) comprised 51% of total FDI in 2012, despite the general slowdown in global 
trade and FDI.

6.  There are three opportunities for RCI to address broader development issues in the 
region. 
 
(i)  Asia and the Pacific is home to approximately two-thirds of the world’s poor, and 
the  region’s  future  will  be  challenged  by  slowing  productivity  growth,  weak 
competitiveness,  and  growing  inequalities  and  vulnerabilities.  These  are 
structural  reform  issues  that  require  RCI  policies  that  complement  domestic 
policy reform. 
(ii)  While East and Southeast Asia have benefited from trade and FDI-driven growth 
from  the  spread  of  production  networks,  other  subregions  are  much  less 
integrated. Countries in the Pacific, in particular, face daunting challenges in 
accessing external markets due to their market size and distance from major 
markets—physical  obstacles  that  are  often  exacerbated  by  supply-side 
constraints  such  as  poor  infrastructure  and  weak  productive  capacities.  The 
opportunities for faster growth of trade and investment between subregions also 
need to be garnered for other parts of the region beyond East and Southeast 
Asia.   
(iii)  There  is  a  need  to  address  issues  that  naturally  transcend  borders  and 
subregions, such as climate change, disaster risk management and associated 
institutional coordination, as well as challenges that have resulted from increased 
integration, such as human trafficking and the spread of communicable diseases. 
Addressing these issues will not only require greater investments in regional 
public  goods,  but  also  more  emphasis  on  mainstreaming  social  and 
environmental  interventions  in  the  design  of  RCI  initiatives  in    cross-border 
infrastructure, trade, and investment. 
 
7.  The development issues outlined above call for a better execution of ADB’s RCI Strategy. 
ADB’s RCI operations have thus far focused on improving connectivity under Pillar 1, but the 
evolving  development  landscape  clearly  suggests  the  importance  of  seeking  greater 
complementarities across the four pillars of the RCI Strategy. In this light, the midterm review 
highlighted the need for a “second generation RCI” agenda that will build on the connectivity 
between economies and markets, to seek to promote competiveness in connected markets, and 
address shared resilience and vulnerability issues.9 In addition, the changes in the development 
partner  landscape  in  RCI,  with  new  region-wide  RCI  initiatives  (e.g.,  the  Regional 
Comprehensive Economic Partnership, Trans Pacific Partnership, Eurasian Economic Union, 
One Belt One Road Initiative of the People’s Republic of China [PRC], Japan's High Quality 
Infrastructure Initiative, the Republic of Korea's Eurasia Initiative, and India's Act East Policy, 
among others) require a stronger understanding of those initiatives and how to forge effective 
collaboration around institutional arrangements.  
 
8.  The  outputs  of  this  TA  will  support  the  implementation  of  the  midterm  review’s 
recommendations  by  producing  operationally  relevant  knowledge  work  that  will  help  guide 
ADB’s future operations in RCI.  
 
                                                
9 Figure 2 in the Management approved RCI Operational Plan concept paper (approved August 2015) shows the 
distinction between first and second generation RCI.

3
III.  THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  impact  will  be  the  implementation  of  RCI  initiatives  that  will  help  address  the 
emerging  development  challenges  faced  by  ADB’s  DMCs. 10  The  outcome  will  be  the 
identification of new and/or enhanced RCI initiatives that can be incorporated in ADB’s future 
operations in RCI. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA’s three key outputs are as follows:   
 
11.  Output  1  :  Preparation  of  knowledge  products  on  regional  cooperation  and 
integration.  These  will examine broad RCI issues reflecting the four pillars of ADB’s RCI 
Strategy and help operationalize the “second-generation RCI” agenda called for under the 
Strategy  2020  midterm  review.  To  be  developed  in  close  collaboration  with  ADB  regional 
departments, the TA will produce two major RCI knowledge products: 
 
(i)  A  background  paper  on  regionalism  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific:  emerging 
trends, opportunities, and challenges. This study will analyze how RCI can 
address  emerging  development  challenges  in  the  region,  including  slowing 
productivity  growth,  weak  competitiveness,  and  growing  inequalities  and 
vulnerabilities; determine the prospects for expanding RCI beyond subregions; 
and explore the implications of emerging drivers of inter-subregional and inter-
regional integration, such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, 
Trans Pacific Partnership, Eurasian Economic Union, PRC’s One Belt One Road 
Initiative, Japan's High Quality Infrastructure Initiative, the Republic of Korea's 
Eurasia Initiative, and India's Act East Policy, among others. 
(ii)  A  thematic  paper  on  economic  clusters  and  economic  corridor 
development.  Using  three  country  case  studies,  this  paper  will  (i)  examine 
approaches and concepts for economic cluster and corridor development; (ii) 
explore  the  economic  and  development  impacts  of  economic  clusters  and 
corridors  and  their  role  in  facilitating  regional  supply  chains  and  production 
networks; (iii) identify the factors that contribute to the success and/or failure of 
economic clusters and corridors; and (iv) identify policy reforms, and spatial 
planning of multisector interventions and urbanization needed to support the 
development  of  economic  clusters  and  corridors.  Given  the  interest  and 
engagement of several regional departments in economic corridor development, 
this is designed to provide an overall analytical framework for economic corridors 
across subregions, which can be appropriately tailored, and identify potential 
complementarities between subregional corridors. 
 
12.  Each background and thematic paper will undertake a literature review to utilize and 
maximize ADB’s existing knowledge base and identify the research gaps to be filled by the TA.  
The literature review will also (i) reflect the findings of the Independent Evaluation Department’s 
assessment of ADB’s RCI Strategy implementation; and (ii) consider the results of the RCI 
Roundtable Conference held in 2014, which dealt with the narrower topic of RCI’s role in 
addressing productivity challenges in Asia.    
                                                
10 See paragraph 6, items (i) to (iii) for the list of emerging challenges.

4  
 
13.  The TA will undertake consultations with government officials from selected DMCs, 
subregional forums, ADB staff, and international and local experts to validate the research 
products’ scope, findings, and recommendations. For the thematic paper on economic clusters 
and corridors, the TA will also conduct consultations in selected DMCs with major economic 
cross-border areas. 
 
14.  Output 2 : Publication and launch of consolidated research report at the second 
Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Roundtable  Conference.  The  key  findings  and 
recommendations of the two knowledge products will be consolidated into one research report 
that will be launched at the second RCI Roundtable Conference in November 2016.   
 
15.  Output 3 : Synthesis paper summarizing the implications for ADB’s operations in 
Regional Cooperation and Integration. In order to help define ADB’s future work on RCI, a 
synthesis paper will be prepared to (i) explore the programmatic implications of the research 
findings and policy recommendations; (ii) identify new and/or enhanced RCI initiatives and 
interventions  that  can  be  incorporated  in  ADB’s  RCI  operations;  and  (iii)  determine  any 
necessary improvements in ADB’s institutional arrangements for RCI operations. This synthesis 
paper will be reviewed at the second Roundtable RCI Conference in November 2016 and 
presented at subsequent appropriate subregional and/or regional meetings and events. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $850,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The detailed cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months from December 2015 to December 2016. 
ADB will be the executing agency. The Regional Cooperation and Integration Thematic Group 
(RCI-TG) Secretariat of the Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department will 
serve as the overall coordinator and will be responsible for administering the TA, providing 
overall research guidance, and engaging in collaborative research with consultants. While the 
RCI-TG  Secretariat  will  implement  the  TA,  ADB’s  regional  departments,  Private  Sector 
Operations Department, and Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department will 
provide substantial guidance and inputs in the production of knowledge work that is critically 
important to their respective subregions and operations. The RCI-TG Secretariat will gather 
inputs and comments from these departments through the RCI-TG and the different thematic 
and sector groups within ADB.11 In particular, these departments will be invited to (i) attend the 
first internal consultation workshop to present the results of the literature review and discuss the 
content of the publication to be produced under this TA; (ii) provide comments on the scope, 
methodology, and preliminary drafts of the background and thematic papers; and (iii) provide 
inputs to the synthesis paper exploring the implications of the research findings on ADB’s RCI 
operations. The RCI-TG Secretariat will explore subregional programs’ forums and/or meetings 
that can serve as venues for subregional consultations. 
 
18.  ADB will also coordinate with other global and regional institutions (e.g., the United 
Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, the World Bank, World 
                                                
11 For more details, see http://www.adb.org/about/knowledge-management/sector-thematic-groups-adb.

5
Customs  Organization,  World  Trade  Organization,  and  the  Deutsche Gesellschaft  für 
Internationale Zusammenarbeit) to explore partnerships in producing the knowledge work and 
conduct of other activities under this TA. 
 
19.  The TA will require approximately 29 person-months of international consulting services 
(22 person-months for preparing the background and thematic papers, 6 person-months for 
preparing the synthesis paper, and one person-month for editorial services), 30 person-months 
of national consulting services, and 4.1 person-months of resource persons. All consultants will 
be selected and engaged individually by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). For this TA, hiring a team of individual 
consultants will provide more benefits for ADB than engaging a firm because of the following 
reasons: (i) faster mobilization of consultants, (ii) greater control by ADB staff in selecting and 
managing individual consultants, and (iii) greater flexibility in engaging experts specializing in a 
broad spectrum of RCI-related topics.12  
 
20.  Eleven international consultants will be engaged to prepare the background, thematic, 
and synthesis papers. The consultants are expected to provide the in-depth knowledge and 
expertise  necessary  to  supplement  ADB’s  nascent  knowledge  base  and  skills  on  second-
generation  RCI.  An  economics  editor  will  also  be  engaged  to  help  review  and  edit  the 
knowledge products that will be produced under this TA. Six resource persons will be invited 
either to present or write background papers for regional workshops, or to serve as peer 
reviewers for the knowledge products that will be produced under this TA. 
 
21.  The  TA  will  require  five  national  consultants:  one  to  assist  in  supervising  and 
coordinating the TA activities and outputs, and four to provide research support. A typesetter will 
be sourced from ADB’s Department of External Relations list of accredited service providers 
who will be responsible for graphics and design, typesetting, and page layout. Appendix 3 
provides the outline terms of reference for consultants. 
 
22.  Purchases of equipment (computer hardware and software) and statistical databases will 
be undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from time 
to time) and in coordination with ADB’s Office of Information Systems and Technology and 
Office of Administrative Services, where applicable. After the TA is completed, any procured 
equipment will be disposed in compliance with ADB guidelines on administering grant-financed 
TA projects. Disbursements under this TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The project officer 
and other ADB experts will serve as contributors to the research and development of the 
knowledge products or as resource persons during the workshops to be conducted under this 
TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $850,000 on a grant basis for 
The Future of Regional Cooperation and Integration in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board. 
                                                
12 To reduce administrative burden and improve economy, efficiency, and value for money under the TA, most of the 
international consultants will be given output-based contracts.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  To implement the technical assistance (TA) project, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
through the Regional Cooperation and Integration Thematic Group (RCI-TG) Secretariat of the 
Economic  Research  and  Regional  Cooperation  Department,  will  engage  11    individual 
international consultants to prepare the background, thematic, and synthesis papers, with 28 
person-months  total;  one  economics  editor  for  one  person-month;  five  individual  national 
consultants to provide both administrative and research support for 30 person-months total; and 
six resource persons for 4.1 person-months total. The RCI-TG Secretariat, which will serve as 
the  overall  coordinator,  will  be  responsible  for  providing  overall  research  guidance  and 
consolidating  the  research  outputs  of  the  individual  international  consultants.  Wherever 
possible, the RCI-TG Secretariat will also engage in collaborative research with the consultants.  
 
A.   Individual International Consultants 
 
2.  Lead economist (team leader) (3 person-months). One international economist will be 
engaged to produce a background paper on regionalism in Asia and the Pacific that will analyze 
how  RCI  can  address  emerging  development  challenges  in  the  region,  including  slowing 
productivity  growth,  weak  competitiveness,  and  growing  inequalities  and  vulnerabilities; 
determine the prospects for expanding RCI beyond subregions; and explore the implications of 
emerging  drivers  of  inter-subregional  and  inter-regional  integration,  such  as  the  Regional 
Comprehensive Economic Partnership, Trans Pacific Partnership, Eurasian Economic Union, 
One  Belt  One  Road  Initiative  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China,  Japan's  High  Quality 
Infrastructure Initiative, the Republic of Korea's Eurasia Initiative, and India's Act East Policy, 
among  others.  The  consultant  will  also  assist  the  RCI-TG  Secretariat  in  consolidating  the 
research findings and recommendations. The consultant, preferably with 15 years of relevant 
experience, should have extensive experience in doing economic research involving Asian 
economies and the region. 
3.  In collaboration with the RCI-TG Secretariat, the lead economist will 
(i)  conduct a review of the existing and current literature, including ADB publications 
on regionalism in Asia and the Pacific; 
(ii)  submit the review of literature and analysis on research gaps for the RCI-TG’s 
review;  
(iii)  synthesize submissions from the other contributors, prepare a background paper, 
and present it during internal and external consultation meetings and country 
and/or subregional consultations;  
(iv)  submit the paper for peer review, and revise as needed; 
(v)  attend and present during consultation meetings with ADB regional department 
and/or project team and country and/or subregional consultations; and 
(vi)  assist  in  writing  the  overview  and  concluding  sections  of  the  report  to  be 
published under this TA. 
 
4.  Economists (five international consultants, 10 person-months total). Five international 
economists  will  be  engaged  to  contribute  think  pieces  and  assist  the  lead  economist  in 
producing  the  background  paper.  The  consultants,  preferably  with  15  years  of  relevant 
experience, should have extensive experience in doing economic research involving Asian 
economies and the region. 
 
5.  In collaboration with the RCI-TG Secretariat, the economists will

10  Appendix 3 
(i)  conduct a review of the existing and current literature, including ADB publications 
on regionalism in Asia and the Pacific; 
(ii)  submit the review of literature and analysis on research gaps for the RCI-TG’s 
review;  
(iii)  prepare think pieces and assist the lead economist in producing the background 
paper; and 
(iv)  submit the think pieces for peer review, and revise as needed. 
 
6.  Trade  experts  (three  international  consultants,  9  person-months  total).  Three 
international trade experts will be engaged to prepare the thematic paper on economic clusters 
and  economic  corridor  development.  More  specifically,  the  trade  experts  will  produce  two 
country case studies that will (i) examine approaches and concepts for economic cluster and 
corridor development; (ii) explore the economic and development impacts of economic clusters 
and corridors and their role in facilitating regional supply chains and production networks; (iii) 
identify  the  factors  that  contribute  to  the  success  and/or  failure  of  economic  clusters  and 
corridors; and (iv) identify policy reforms needed to support the development of economic 
clusters and corridors. 
 
7.  The consultants, preferably with 15 years of relevant experience, should have extensive 
research  experience  in  economic  and  international  trade-related  analysis,  including  on 
economic  clusters,  economic  corridors,  and  production  networks,  and  they  should  have 
knowledge of local conditions in the country under the study. 
 
8.  In collaboration with the RCI-TG Secretariat, the trade experts will 
(i)  conduct a review of the existing and current literature on the development of 
economic clusters and corridors in the country under study; 
(ii)  submit the review of literature and analysis on research gaps for the RCI-TG’s 
review;  
(iii)       conduct field surveys and interviews, if necessary;  
(iv)   prepare the country case studies and present them during internal and external 
consultation meetings, and country and/or subregional consultations;  
(v)  submit the studies for peer review, and revise as needed; and 
(vi)  attend and present during consultation meetings with ADB regional department 
and/or project team and country and/or subregional consultations. 
 
9.   Economists  or  institutions  specialists  (two  international  consultants,  6  person-
months total). Two economists or institutions specialists will be engaged to produce a synthesis 
paper that will consolidate the findings and recommendations of the background and thematic 
papers, and examine their implications on ADB’s RCI operations. The consultants, preferably 
with 10 years of relevant experience, should have extensive research experience on RCI and 
should be familiar with ADB’s RCI operations.  
 
10.  In collaboration with the RCI-TG Secretariat, the consultants will prepare a synthesis 
paper that will 
(i)  explore  the  programmatic  implications  of  the  research  findings  and  policy 
recommendations;  
(ii)  identify  new  and/or  enhanced  RCI  initiatives  and  interventions  that  can  be 
incorporated in ADB’s RCI operations; and  
(iii)  determine any necessary improvements in ADB’s institutional arrangements for 
RCI operations.

Appendix 3  11 
11.  The consultants will assist the RCI-TG Secretariat in presenting and soliciting comments 
on the synthesis paper during internal consultation meetings.  
 
12.  Economics editor (1 person-month). The editor will review and edit the contents of the 
publication produced under this TA to ensure coherence, readability, and the highest publication 
standards. Specific tasks include the following: 
(i)  rewrite, add, or delete information, and help revise various pages or sections, if 
necessary, to tighten arguments, fill in gaps in the discussions, and ensure the 
smooth flow of ideas; 
(ii)  examine the tables, figures, and charts to ensure data consistency within pages 
and documents; and suggest deletions and additions to ensure that they are 
useful; 
(iii)  edit the pages for publication; and 
(iv)  ensure that documents adhere to ADB style and usage and conform to high 
publication standards. 
 
B.   Individual National Consultants 
 
13.  Research assistants (three national consultants, 6 person-months total). Three national 
consultants will be engaged to provide research support for the thematic paper on economic 
clusters  and  economic corridor  development. The  consultants  will  be  economists, financial 
specialists or statisticians with extensive experience in economic and financial data processing 
and analysis for a minimum of 7 years, strong communication skills (including English), ability to 
coordinate with government offices that deal with national statistics, advanced skills in gathering 
data, and proficiency in using software with standard applications. The consultants will be 
engaged locally and be based in the country where the study is being conducted. Under the 
supervision of the RCI-TG Secretariat, the consultants will 
(i)  assist  in  gathering  and  analyzing  data  for  the  thematic  paper  on  economic 
clusters and economic corridor development;  
(ii)  assist in arranging the country consultations to define the scope of the paper and 
validate the paper’s findings;  
(iii)  assist in the conduct of country surveys and process their results;  
(iv)  organize and assist in the conduct of in-country workshops and meetings; and  
(v)  perform other tasks as required. 
 
14.   Program coordinator (12 person-months). The consultant will have solid experience 
and a good reputation in coordinating research production and development. He or she will 
have a good knowledge of economics and will have strong analytical and communication skills. 
Under  the supervision  of  the  RCI-TG  Secretariat, the  consultant  will  be  stationed  at  ADB 
headquarters in Manila and will 
 
(i)  assist the project team by arranging meetings and preparing the materials and 
documents required; 
(ii)  liaise  with  host  governments,  consultants,  and  ADB  staff  in  organizing  the 
regional  workshops,  and  assist  the  team  in  organizing  country  consultation 
meetings; 
(iii)  organize video conferences (including all logistical and administrative support 
such as budget summaries), prepare minutes of the meetings conducted under 
the TA, and draft TA progress reports; 
(iv)  coordinate logistical arrangements for regional workshops, including travel, hotel 
reservations, and venue arrangements;

12  Appendix 3 
(v)  coordinate with resource persons and participants regarding their engagement 
and participation in workshops and training; 
(vi)  prepare and disseminate materials to participants for any events organized under 
this TA; 
(vii)  liaise  with  ADB’s  Department  of  External  Relations  on  the  production  of 
knowledge products; 
(viii)  prepare and maintain a database of consultants and participants; 
(ix)  provide backstopping during meetings and workshops and provide support to in-
country meetings;  
(x)  attend and provide support to ADB missions conducted under this TA, if needed; 
and 
(xi)  perform other tasks as required. 
 
15.   Research associate (12 person-months). The consultant will have solid experience in 
doing economic research. He or she should have strong analytical and communication skills. 
Under  the supervision  of  the  RCI-TG  Secretariat, the  consultant  will  be  stationed  at  ADB 
headquarters in Manila and will 
(i)  prepare RCI-related knowledge products, as may be requested by the project 
leader and/or TA team members; 
(ii)  assist in the preparation of the final publication and other dissemination materials 
under this TA; 
(iii)  provide research and editorial assistance to the background paper and thematic 
papers produced under this TA;  
(iv)  provide other research and general administrative support as may be requested 
by the project leader and/or other TA team members; and 
(v)  attend and provide support to ADB missions conducted under this TA, if needed. 
 
C.   Resource Persons  
 
16.   Resource persons (six resource persons, 4.1 person-months total). ADB will engage 
resource persons for short periods during the regional workshops and/or consultation meetings 
to  make  presentations,  prepare  background  papers  for  the  said  events,  or  serve  as  peer 
reviewers for the background and thematic papers.
